articles.title: Big Tech will survive Trump tariffs, CEO of $4 trillion NVIDIA says
articles.content: NVIDIA CEO Jensen Huang spoke to USA TODAY about tariffs, trade and his trip to China after a meeting with President Donald Trump at the White House.

articles.title: Apple Offers as Much as $150 Million for Formula One U.S. Rights
articles.content: The bid puts F1 on track for a significantly more lucrative deal than it has with its current partner, Disney’s ESPN.

articles.title: Why Apple shouldn't replace Tim Cook yet
articles.content: An analyst at LightShed Partners suggested that Apple (AAPL) should replace CEO Tim Cook. Tufts University Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy adjunct associate professor Gautam Mukunda doesn't think the tech giant should be rushing to replace its leader. He explains why in the video above. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Market Domination Overtime here.

articles.title: Nvidia Becomes First Company Ever to Reach $4 Trillion Market Cap. Could the Growth Stock Have Even More Room to Run?
articles.content: Nvidia surpassed $4 trillion in market cap on Wednesday, becoming the first company ever to do so.  The investment thesis is backed by measurable results.  Nvidia's success largely depends on its top customers converting AI spending into earnings growth.

articles.title: EU plans new tax on big corporates to boost budget -FT
articles.content: The draft documents indicated that the European Commission, the bloc’s executive arm, had dropped plans to target US Big Tech groups like Apple and Meta with a tax on digital services, though they would still be hit by the proposed new broader levy.  News of the plans came as the EU braced for a possible letter from U.S. President Donald Trump outlining planned duties on the United States’ largest trade and investment partner after widening his tariff war in recent days.  Trump has railed against what he sees as the EU’s heavy-handed regulation of Big Tech.

articles.title: Stock Market Today: Stocks Finish In The Red; Dow Jones Index Bears The Brunt Of Selling
articles.content: The major indexes posted losses Friday after the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite hit record highs Thursday.

articles.title: Apple bids for Formula 1 US streaming rights, Business Insider reports
articles.content: The iPhone-maker is poised to win the rights as the leading bidder, the report said, as Walt Disney's ESPN, which currently holds the rights, will not try to match or beat it.  Apple declined a Reuters request for comment, while F1 and its owner Liberty Media did not immediately respond.  The news follows Apple's success with its "F1: The Movie" film starring Brad Pitt, that has grossed over $300 million worldwide as of Friday, according to IMDb's Box Office Mojo.

articles.title: Stock Market Today: Dow Jones Is A Big Loser, Nasdaq Weakens; Circle Internet Makes This Bold Move (Live Coverage)
articles.content: The Dow Jones index dropped Friday on tariff news. Nvidia-backed CoreWeave sank, Levi was a big mover on the stock market today.

articles.title: How Apple's 'consumer-first' approach plays into the AI race
articles.content: Apple's (AAPL) slow-and-steady approach to artificial intelligence (AI) adoption is drawing fresh scrutiny as the company faces pressure to accelerate innovation. Yahoo Finance Technology Editor Dan Howley and TECHnalysis Research president Bob O'Donnell join Market Domination to discuss whether Apple needs new leadership and how it’s playing the artificial intelligence (AI) race. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Market Domination here.

articles.title: Apple's 2026 Product Pipeline
articles.content: Bloomberg's Mark Gurman breaks down the new hardware set to be released by Apple in 2026 including new Macs, iPads, an iPhone 17E and a brand new external Mac Monitor. He joins Romaine Bostick on "Bloomberg Tech" to discuss.
